fact: The RCA Mark II Sound Synthesizer is installed at the Columbia-Princeton Electronic Music Center in New York, becoming the first programmable electronic synthesizer and laying the foundations of academic electronic music.
Wendy Carlos releases 'Switched-On Bach', an album recorded entirely with Moog synthesizers. It becomes a commercial success and introduces electronic music to a mainstream audience.
Kraftwerk is officially formed in Düsseldorf, Germany. The group pioneers minimalist electronic music, influencing future genres such as techno, electro, synth-pop, and hip hop.

Donna Summer releases 'I Feel Love', produced by Giorgio Moroder. Its fully synthesized rhythm and hypnotic structure revolutionize disco and directly influence techno, house, and electronic dance music.
Yellow Magic Orchestra is formed in Tokyo. The band popularizes electronic pop and early sampling techniques, influencing synth-pop, techno, and video game music worldwide.
Roland releases the TR-808 drum machine. Initially a commercial failure, its deep bass and synthetic percussion later become fundamental to hip hop, electro, techno, and house music.
The Roland TB-303 Bass Line is released. Originally intended for guitar accompaniment, it later becomes the defining sound of acid house after being adopted by Chicago producers.
Frankie Knuckles becomes resident DJ at The Warehouse in Chicago, where disco records are mixed with electronic drum machines, giving birth to house music.
The MIDI (Musical Instrument Digital Interface) standard is introduced, allowing electronic instruments and computers to communicate, revolutionizing music production and live performance.
Herbie Hancock releases 'Rockit', one of the first mainstream tracks to feature electronic funk, turntablism, and synthesized rhythms, bridging electronic music and hip hop culture.
The compilation 'Techno! The New Dance Sound of Detroit' is released, spreading the term 'techno' internationally and introducing Detroit techno to European audiences.
The Second Summer of Love takes place in the UK, as acid house and rave culture explode through illegal parties and warehouse events, reshaping youth culture.
The Roland TB-303 becomes synonymous with acid house, especially after tracks like 'Acid Tracks' define the squelching bass sound of the genre.
The fall of the Berlin Wall accelerates the rise of Berlin’s techno scene, with abandoned buildings and underground clubs becoming hubs for electronic music experimentation.
The Tresor club opens in Berlin, becoming one of the most influential techno clubs in the world and a bridge between Detroit techno and European electronic music.
Massive Attack releases 'Blue Lines', an album that blends hip hop, dub, soul, and electronics, establishing the foundations of the trip-hop genre.
Warp Records releases the 'Artificial Intelligence' compilation, promoting electronic music designed for listening rather than dancing and helping define the IDM movement.
Aphex Twin releases 'Selected Ambient Works 85–92', a landmark album that blends ambient textures with techno rhythms and shapes the future of IDM.
The UK Criminal Justice Act targets unlicensed raves and outdoor electronic music events, marking a turning point and decline in the original UK rave movement.
Daft Punk releases 'Homework', popularizing the French house movement and bringing filtered disco-infused house music to a global audience.
Aphex Twin releases 'Come to Daddy', pushing experimental electronic music into the mainstream and becoming an iconic release of the IDM genre.
The first Ultra Music Festival takes place in Miami, helping transform electronic dance music festivals into large-scale global events.
Napster launches as a peer-to-peer MP3 sharing platform, dramatically changing how electronic music is distributed and consumed worldwide.
The Detroit Electronic Music Festival debuts, celebrating the city’s techno heritage and becoming a major annual event for the global techno community.
Ableton Live is released, introducing a new approach to music production and live performance through loop-based composition and real-time manipulation.
Dubstep begins to emerge in South London, combining UK garage, dub, and dark bass textures, eventually becoming a global bass music phenomenon.
Daft Punk releases 'Discovery', blending house, disco, pop, and synthwave aesthetics into one of the most influential electronic albums of all time.
Justice releases '†' (Cross), defining the aggressive electro-house sound of the bloghouse era and influencing a new generation of producers.
Spotify launches, accelerating the shift toward music streaming and reshaping how electronic music is discovered, shared, and monetized.
Daft Punk’s 'Random Access Memories' wins multiple Grammy Awards, highlighting a renewed interest in analog production and live instrumentation within electronic music.
Modular synthesizers experience a global resurgence, with Eurorack systems becoming central to experimental, ambient, and techno music production.
Global COVID-19 lockdowns force clubs and festivals to close, leading DJs and producers to adopt livestreaming and virtual events as new performance formats.
Pierre Schaeffer introduces 'musique concrète' in Paris, experimenting with tape loops, found sounds, and audio manipulation, marking one of the earliest forms of electronic music.
Karlheinz Stockhausen begins producing electronic compositions in Germany, combining serialism and electronic sound generation, deeply influencing avant-garde and experimental music.
Robert Moog commercializes the Moog modular synthesizer, making electronic sound synthesis accessible to musicians outside academic institutions.
Brian Eno begins experimenting with tape loops and generative music concepts, later becoming a key figure in the development of ambient music.
Kraftwerk releases 'Autobahn', achieving international success and demonstrating that electronic music can reach mass audiences.
Gary Numan releases 'The Pleasure Principle', bringing synthesizers to the top of the UK charts and accelerating the rise of synth-pop.
Detroit producers Juan Atkins, Derrick May, and Kevin Saunderson begin shaping what will become known as Detroit techno, inspired by futurism and electronic funk.
House music spreads from Chicago to New York and Europe, becoming a dominant club sound and spawning numerous subgenres.
The track 'Acid Tracks' by Phuture is released, officially defining the acid house sound through the use of the Roland TB-303.
Rave culture expands rapidly across Europe, with large-scale illegal parties and free festivals becoming central to youth counterculture.
Jungle music emerges in the UK, characterized by fast breakbeats, heavy bass, and reggae influences, later evolving into drum and bass.
Drum and bass becomes a defined genre in the UK, with labels and clubs supporting a darker, more technical evolution of jungle.
The Goa trance scene gains international recognition, blending psychedelic aesthetics with repetitive electronic rhythms.
Minimal techno gains popularity in Europe, focusing on stripped-down rhythms, subtle modulation, and long-form club tracks.
The rise of online music forums and digital labels accelerates the globalization of electronic music communities.
Electroclash peaks as a genre, merging 1980s synth aesthetics with punk attitude and club culture.
Berlin solidifies its status as a global techno capital, with clubs like Berghain defining a raw, industrial club sound.
Bedroom producers increasingly rely on laptops and software-based studios, democratizing electronic music production.
Bass music scenes diversify globally, with hybrid styles blending dubstep, techno, house, and experimental electronic music.
Hardware synthesizers and drum machines experience a revival as artists seek tactile workflows alongside digital tools.
Artificial intelligence and generative algorithms begin to influence experimental electronic music composition.
Hybrid live sets combining modular synths, visuals, and real-time performance become increasingly common in electronic music festivals.
